data.title: WCW Title Histories
data.text:
Title Histories

Cruiserweight Tag Titles History

March 18, 2001: Elix Skipper and Kid Romeo beat Kidman and Rey Mysterio Jr. in the tournament final to win the titles, WCW Greed, Jacksonville, Florida.

March 26, 2001: Kidman and Rey Mysterio Jr. win the titles, WCW Monday Nitro, Panama City, Florida.

WCW Hardcore Title History

November 21, 1999: Screamin' Norman Smiley defeats Brian Knobs to become the first WCW Hardcore Champion, Mayhem, Toronto, Ontario.

January 10, 2000: Brian Knobs over Smiley, Erie, Pennsylvania.

February 7, 2000: Bam Bam Bigelow beats Knobs, Monday Nitro, Tulsa, Oklahoma.

February 20, 2000: Brian Knobs regains the title, Superbrawl 2000.

February 28, 2000: 3-Count (Evan Karagias, Shannon Moore and Shane Helms) over Knobs in a Handicap Match, Monday Nitro, Minneapolis, Minnesota.

March 19, 2000: Brian Knobs regains the title in a Gauntlet Match, Uncensored, Miami, Florida.

April 10, 2000: The "new regime" (Eric Bischoff and Vince Russo) strips all WCW champions of their respective titles. All titles are declared vacant, Monday Nitro, Denver, Colorado.

April 12, 2000: Terry Funk and Norman Smiley defeat Fit Finlay and Brian Knobs in a hardcore tag team match, WCW Thunder, Colorado Springs, Colorado (taped April 11, 2000). The match stipulation was that the winning team would face off for the Hardcore title at the Spring Stampede PPV.

April 16, 2000: Terry Funk beats Norman Smiley, Spring Stampede, Chicago, Illinois.

June 5, 2000: Eric Bischoff over Funk, Monday Nitro, Atlanta, Georgia.

June 7, 2000: Eric Bischoff relinquishes the title and announces that the winner of a match between The Mamalukes and The Wall will become the new champion(s), WCW Thunder, Knoxville, Tennessee (taped June 6).

June 7, 2000: The Mamalukes (Big Vito and Johnny The Bull) defeat The Wall, WCW Thunder, Knoxville, Tennessee (taped June 6). Big Vito takes possession of the title for earning the pinfall over The Wall.

July 24, 2000: Lance Storm beats Big Vito in a title for title (US Title vs. Hardcore Title) match to win the WCW Hardcore Championship, Monday Nitro, Cleveland, Ohio.

August 14, 2000: Lance Storm relinquishes the title and presents it to Carl "The Rave" Oulette, WCW Monday Nitro, Kelowna, British Columbia.

August 14, 2000: Norman Smiley defeats Oulette, WCW Monday Nitro, Kelowna, British Columbia.

September 27, 2000: Norman Smiley is stripped of the title by temporary WCW booker "Above Average" Mike Sanders, WCW Thunder, Wilkes Barre, Pennsylvania (taped September 26). A tournament is announced involving four wrestlers; Reno, Johnny The Bull, Sgt. AWOL and Crowbar.

October 2, 2000: AWOL defeats Reno in the finals of the WCW Hardcore Title Tournament. The decision is reversed by Mike Sanders, put in charge by Vince Russo. Reno therefore becomes the new WCW Hardcore Champion, WCW Monday Nitro, San Francisco, California.

November 8, 2000: Crowbar beats Reno, WCW Thunder, Chicago, Illinois (taped November 6).

December 17, 2000: Terry Funk over Crowbar, WCW Starrcade, Washington, D.C.

January 14, 2001: Meng defeats Funk and Crowbar in a three way dance, WCW Sin, Indianapolis, Indiana.

Meng signs with the WWF and makes a surprise WWF debut at the WWF Royal Rumble 2001. WCW ceases to mention Meng or the Hardcore Title.

WCW Cruiserweight Title History

October 27, 1991: Flyin' Brian Pillman defeats Richard Morton in the tournament final, Chattanooga, Tennessee.

December 25, 1991: Jushin "Thunder" Liger over Pillman, Atlanta, Georgia.

February 29, 1992: Flyin' Brian Pillman regains the title, Milwaukee, Wisconsin.

June 20, 1992: Scotty Flamingo beats Pillman, Augusta, Georgia.

July 5, 1992: Brad Armstrong over Flamingo, Atlanta, Georgia.

September 2, 1992: Armstrong is stripped of the title (at Clash of Champions XX) for failing to defend within the 30-day limit. A tournament was scheduled for early 1993, but never took place.

March 20, 1996: Shinjiro Ohtani defeats Wild Pegasus (Chris Benoit) to become the first cruiserweight champion, Nagoya, Japan.

May 2, 1996: Dean Malenko beats Ohtani, Lake Buena Vista, Florida.

July 8, 1996: Rey Misterio Jr. over Malenko, Lake Buena Vista, Florida.

October 27, 1996: Dean Malenko regains the title, Las Vegas, Nevada.

December 29, 1996: Ultimo Dragon defeats Malenko, Nashville, Tennessee.

January 21, 1997: Dean Malenko wins back the title, Milwaukee, Wisconsin.

February 23, 1997: Syxx (Sean Waltman) over Malenko, San Francisco, California.

June 28, 1997: Chris Jericho beats Syxx, Inglewood, California.

July 28, 1997: Alex Wright defeats Jericho, Charleston, West Virginia.

August 12, 1997: Chris Jericho regains the title, Colorado Springs, Colorado.

September 14, 1997: Eddy Guerrero over Jericho, Winston-Salem, North Carolina.

October 26, 1997: Rey Misterio Jr. beats Guerrero, Las Vegas, Nevada.

November 10, 1997: Eddy Guerrero regains the belt, Memphis, Tennessee.

December 29, 1997: Ultimo Dragon defeats Misterio Jr., Baltimore, Maryland.

January 8, 1998: Juventud Guerrera beats the Dragon, Daytona Beach, Florida.

January 15, 1998: Rey Misterio Jr. over Guerrera, Lakeland, Florida.

January 24, 1998: Chris Jericho defeats Misterio Jr., Dayton, Ohio.

May 17, 1998: Dean Malenko beats Jericho, Worcester, Massachusetts.

June 11, 1998: Malenko vacates the title when Jericho protests that he hadn't signed a contract to wrestle Malenko on May 17, since Malenko earned his title shot by winning a cruiserweight battle royal under a mask.

June 15, 1998: Chris Jericho over Malenko in a rematch for the vacant title, Uniondale, New York. Jericho won the match via disqualification, and is awarded the championship.

July 12, 1998: Rey Misterio Jr. beats Jericho, San Diego, California. The title is returned to Jericho the next night due to the interference of Dean Malenko during Jericho's title loss, as Malenko had been suspended.

August 8, 1998: Juventud Guerrera defeats Jericho, Sturgis, South Dakota.

September 14, 1998: Billy Kidman over Guerrera, Greenville, South Carolina.

November 16, 1998: Juventud Guerrera regains the title, Wichita, Kansas.

November 22, 1998: Billy Kidman wins back the title, Auburn Hills, Michigan.

March 15, 1999: Rey Misterio Jr. beats Kidman, Cincinnati, Ohio.

April 19, 1999: Psychosis defeats Misterio Jr., Juventud Guerrera and Blitzkrieg in a Four-Way Match, Gainesville, Florida.

April 26, 1999: Rey Misterio Jr. regains the title (his fifth), Fargo, North Dakota.

August 19, 1999: Lenny Lane over Misterio Jr., Lubbock, Texas.

October 4, 1999: Psychosis is announced as being the champion following a fictitious title victory over Lane, Kansas City, Missouri.

October 4, 1999: The Disco Inferno defeats Psychosis, Kansas City, Missouri.

November 21, 1999: Evan Karagias beats The Disco Inferno, Mayhem, Toronto, Ontario.

December 19, 1999: Madusa over Karagias, Washington, DC.

January 16, 2000: Oklahoma (Ed Ferrera) defeats Madusa, Souled Out, Cincinnati, Ohio.

January 17, 2000: Oklahoma forfeits the WCW Cruiserweight Championship, stating that he'd done what he'd set out to do, and that's win the "Battle of the Sexes" with Madusa. A tournament is planned to crown a new champion.

February 20, 2000: (The Artist Formerly Known As) Prince Iaukea beats Lash Leroux in the finals of the Cruiserweight Championship Tournament, Superbrawl 2000.

March 30, 2000: Billy Kidman over The Artist, Baltimore, Maryland.

March 31, 2000: The Artist regains the title, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania.

April 10, 2000: The "new regime" (Eric Bischoff and Vince Russo) strips all WCW champions of their respective titles. All titles are declared vacant, Monday Nitro, Denver, Colorado.

A "Suicide Six Man" match is announced to crown a new champion.

April 16, 2000: "Hard Knox" Chris Candido defeats The Artist, Lash Leroux, Crowbar, Juventud Guerrera and Shannon Moore in a "Suicide Six Man" match to win the title, Spring Stampede, Chicago, Illinois.

May 15, 2000: A mixed tag team match is announced, with the rules being that the one to score the pinfall would win the WCW Cruiserweight Championship.

May 15, 2000: Daffney (teaming with Crowbar) pins Tammy Sytch (teaming with Chris Candido), Monday Nitro, Biloxi, Missouri. Bother members of the winning team lay claim to the title.

May 22, 2000: Daffney beats Crowbar in a match to determine the rightful champion, Monday Nitro, Grand Rapids, Michigan.

June 7, 2000: Lieutenant Loco (Chavo Guerrero Jr.) defeats Disco Inferno and Daffney in a triple threat match, WCW Thunder, Knoxville, Tennessee (taped June 6).

July 31, 2000: Lance Storm over Lt. Loco, Monday Nitro, Cincinnati, Ohio.

August 14, 2000: Lance Storm relinquishes the title and presents it to "Prime Time" Elix Skipper, WCW Monday Nitro, Kelowna, British Columbia.

October 2, 2000: Mike Sanders defeats Elix Skipper, WCW Monday Nitro, San Francisco, California.

December 6, 2000: Chavo Guerrero Jr. over Sanders, WCW Thunder, Lincoln, Nebraska (taped December 4).

March 18, 2001: Shane Helms beats Guerrero Jr., WCW Greed PPV, Jacksonville, Florida.

:July 5, 2001 Billy Kidman beats Helms, WWF Smackdown, Tacoma, Washington. (Taped July 3)

NWA\WCW Television Title History

March 7, 1984: Mark Youngblood defeats "Dirty" Dick Slater in the finals of the tournament to become the National Wrestling Alliance (NWA) Mid-Atlantic television champion. Slater's U.S. title was not on the line during the match.

May, 1984: Tully Blanchard wins the title from Youngblood.

March 16, 1985: Dusty Rhodes beats Blanchard for the title, Greensboro, North Carolina. The title becomes recognized as the world television championship.

April 28, 1985: Tully Blanchard over Rhodes, Charlotte, North Carolina.

July 6, 1985: Dusty Rhodes regains the title, Charlotte, North Carolina.

September 29, 1985: Rhodes' leg is broken during an attack by Ric Flair and Arn & Ole Anderson, Atlanta, Georgia.

October 19, 1985: Rhodes is stripped of the title after being unable to defend it.

January 4, 1986: Arn Anderson defeats Wahoo McDaniel in the finals of the tournament, Greensboro, North Carolina.

September 9, 1986: Dusty Rhodes over Anderson, Columbia, South Carolina.

November 27, 1986: Tully Blanchard beats Rhodes in a "First Blood Match", Greensboro, North Carolina.

August 17, 1987: Nikita Koloff defeats Blanchard, Fayetteville, North Carolina.

November 26, 1987: Koloff beats Terry Taylor to unify the NWA and UWF TV titles, Chicago, Illinois.

January 26, 1988: Mike Rotundo over Koloff, Raleigh, North Carolina.

December 26, 1988: Rick Steiner defeats Rotundo, Norfolk, Virginia.

February 20, 1989: Mike Rotundo regains the title, Chicago, Illinois.

March 31, 1989: Sting (Steve Borden) over Rotundo, Atlanta, Georgia.

July 23, 1989: The title is held up following a match between Sting and The Great Muta in Baltimore, Maryland. Sting pinned Muta, but tapes later revealed that Muta's shoulders were off the mat. A rematch is ordered.

September 3, 1989: The Great Muta defeats Sting, Atlanta, Georgia.

January 2, 1990: Arn Anderson over Muta, Gainesville, Georgia.

December 4, 1990: The Z-Man (Tom Zenk) beats Anderson, Atlanta, Georgia.

January 14, 1991: Arn Anderson regains the title, Perry, Georgia.

January, 1991: With the NWA no longer operating as an organization, the championship becomes recognized exclusively as the WCW world television title.

May 19, 1991: "Beautiful" Bobby Eaton defeats Anderson, St. Petersburg, Florida.

June 3, 1991: "Stunning" Steve Austin beats Eaton, Birmingham, Alabama.

April 27, 1992: Barry Windham over Austin in a best-of-three-falls match, Atlanta, Georgia.

May 23, 1992: Steve Austin regains the title, Chattanooga, Tennessee.

September 2, 1992: Ricky Steamboat defeats Austin in a No Disqualification Match, Atlanta, Georgia.

September 29, 1992: Scott Steiner beats Steamboat, Columbus, Georgia.

November, 1992: The title is vacated when Scott (and brother Rick) jump to the World Wrestling Federation.

March 2, 1993: Paul Orndorff defeats Erik Watts in the tournament final, Macon, Georgia.

August 18, 1993: Ricky Steamboat over Orndorff, Daytona Beach, Florida.

September 19, 1993: Lord Steven Regal beats Steamboat, Houston, Texas.

May 2, 1994: Larry Zbysko defeats Regal, Atlanta, Georgia.

June 23, 1994: Lord Steven Regal regains the title, Charleston, South Carolina.

September 18, 1994: Johnny B. Badd (Marc Mero) beats Regal, Roanoke, Virginia.

January 8, 1995: Arn Anderson over Badd, Atlanta, Georgia.

June 18, 1995: The Renegade defeats Anderson, Dayton, Ohio.

September 17, 1995: Diamond Dallas Page beats The Renegade, Asheville, North Carolina.

October 29, 1995: Johnny B. Badd over Page, Detroit, Michigan.

February 17, 1996: Lex Luger defeats Badd, Baltimore, Maryland.

February 18, 1996: Johnny B. Badd regains the title, Norfolk, Virginia.

March 6, 1996: Lex Luger wins back the title, Macon, Georgia.

August 20, 1996: Lord Steven Regal beats Luger, Dalton, Georgia.

February 17, 1997: Prince Iaukea defeats Regal, Tampa, Florida.

April 7, 1997: Ultimo Dragon over Iaukea, Huntsville, Alabama.

May 18, 1997: Lord Steven Regal wins the title, Charlotte, North Carolina.

July 22, 1997: Ultimo Dragon regains the belt, Jacksonville, Florida.

August 21, 1997: "Das Wunderkind" Alex Wright beats Dragon, Nashville, Tennessee.

September 22, 1997: The Disco Inferno defeats Wright, Salt Lake City, Utah.

November 3, 1997: Perry Saturn over Inferno, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

December 8, 1997: The Disco Inferno regains the title, Buffalo, New York.

December 29, 1997: Booker T. beats Inferno, Baltimore, Maryland.

February 16, 1998: Rick Martel defeats Booker T., Tampa, Florida.

February 22, 1998: Booker T. wins back the title, San Francisco, California.

April 30, 1998: Chris Benoit over Booker T., Augusta, Georgia.

May 1, 1998: Booker T. regains the title, Greenville, South Carolina.

May 2, 1998: Chris Benoit wins back the gold, Charleston, South Carolina.

May 3, 1998: Booker T. again regains the belt, Savannah, Georgia.

May 4, 1998: Dave Finlay defeats Booker T., Indianapolis, Indiana.

June 14, 1998: Booker T. wins his fifth title, Baltimore, Maryland.

August 10, 1998: "Lionheart" Chris Jericho beats Stevie Ray (who substitutes for his brother Booker T., claiming that Booker T. is injured and can't defend), Rapid City, South Dakota.

November 30, 1998: Konnan over Jericho, Chattanooga, Tennessee.

December 28, 1998: Scott Steiner defeats Konnan, Baltimore, Maryland.

March 14, 1999: Booker T. beats Steiner, Louisville, Kentucky.

May 9, 1999: Rick Steiner over Booker T., St. Louis, Missouri.

September 13, 1999: Chris Benoit defeats Steiner, Chapel Hill, North Carolina.

October 24, 1999: Rick Steiner regains the title, Halloween Havoc, Las Vegas, Nevada.

November 21, 1999: Scott Hall is awarded the title after Steiner is unable to defend due to injury, Mayhem, Toronto, Ontario.

November 29, 1999: Scott Hall throws the belt in a garbage can, thus forfeiting it, Monday Nitro, Detroit, Michigan.

February 19, 2000: "Hacksaw" Jim Duggan finds the TV title belt in the garbage can that Scott Hall had thrown it into. He declares himself the WCW Television Champion, WCW Saturday Night.

April 10, 2000: The "new regime" (Eric Bischoff and Vince Russo) strips all WCW champions of their respective titles. All titles are declared vacant, Monday Nitro, Denver, Colorado.

NWA\WCW Tag Team Titles History

March, 1975: Gene & Ole Anderson win the title tournament and become the National Wrestling Alliance (NWA) tag team champions (Mid Atlantic region), California.

March, 1976: Wahoo McDaniel & Rufus R. Jones beat the Andersons.

March, 1976: Gene & Ole Anderson regain the titles.

May, 1976: Tim Woods & Dino Bravo defeat the Andersons.

July, 1976: Gene & Ole Anderson win back the titles.

December 25, 1976: Ric Flair & Greg Valentine over the Andersons, Greensboro, North Carolina.

May 8, 1977: Gene & Ole Anderson regain the titles, Charlotte, North Carolina.

September, 1977: Dick Slater & Dusty Rhodes beat the Andersons, Atlanta, Georgia.

October, 1977: Gene & Ole Anderson win their fifth tag team championship.

October 30, 1977: Ric Flair & Greg Valentine beat the Andersons.

April, 1978: Flair & Valentine are stripped of the belts.

April 23, 1978: Paul Jones & Ricky Steamboat beat Flair and Valentine in the finals of a 10 team tournament, Greensboro, North Carolina.

June 7, 1978: Baron Von Raschke & Greg Valentine defeat Jones and Steamboat, Raleigh, North Carolina.

December, 1978: Jimmy Snuka & Paul Orndorff over Von Raschke and Valentine.

April 28, 1979: Baron Von Raschke & Paul Jones beat Snuka & Orndorff.

August 8, 1979: Ric Flair & Blackjack Mulligan defeat Von Raschke & Jones, Greensboro, North Carolina.

August 22, 1979: Baron Von Raschke & Paul Jones regain the titles, Raleigh, North Carolina.

October 24, 1979: Ricky Steamboat & Jay Youngblood over Von Raschke & Jones, Raleigh, North Carolina.

March 29, 1980: Ray Stevens & Greg Valentine defeat Steamboat & Youngblood, Charlotte, North Carolina.

May 10, 1980: Ricky Steamboat & Jay Youngblood regain the titles, Greensboro, North Carolina.

June 22, 1980: Ray Stevens & Jimmy Snuka beat Steamboat & Youngblood, Greensboro, North Carolina.

November 27, 1980: Paul Jones & The Masked Superstar (Bill Eadie) defeat Stevens & Snuka, Greensboro, North Carolina.

February 22, 1981: Ray Stevens & Ivan Koloff over Jones & The Superstar, Greensboro, North Carolina.

March 22, 1981: Paul Jones & The Masked Superstar regain the titles, Greensboro, North Carolina.

May 1, 1981: Gene & Ole Anderson beat Jones & The Superstar, Richmond, Virginia.

December, 1981: The Andersons are stripped of the titles due to their inability to defend them following an injury suffered by Gene Anderson in October, 1981.

February 28, 1982: Ole Anderson & Stan Hansen defeat Jack & Jerry Brisco to win the eastern division of a tournament. The team is later awarded the world (NWA Mid Atlantic) titles when the western division tournament winners (Wahoo McDaniel & Don Muraco) split up.

September, 1982: The titles are declared vacant.

September 12, 1982: Sgt. Slaughter & Don Kernodle defeat Shohei "Giant" Baba & Antonio Inoki in the finals of a fictitious tournament, Tokyo, Japan.

March 12, 1983: Ricky Steamboat & Jay Youngblood beat Slaughter & Kernodle, Greensboro, North Carolina.

June 18, 1983: Jack & Jerry Brisco over Steamboat & Youngblood, Greenville, South Carolina.

October 3, 1983: Ricky Steamboat & Jay Youngblood defeat the Briscos, Greenville, South Carolina.

October 21, 1983: Jack & Jerry Brisco regain the titles, Richmond, Virginia.

November 24, 1983: Ricky Steamboat & Jay Youngblood win back the titles (their fifth), Greensboro, North Carolina.

December 25, 1983: Ricky Steamboat announces his retirement. The titles are vacated.

January 8, 1984: Don Kernodle & Bob Orton Jr. beat Dory Funk Jr. & Jimmy Valiant in the tournament final to win the belts, Charlotte, North Carolina.

March 4, 1984: Wahoo McDaniel & Mark Youngblood defeat Kernodle & Orton, Charlotte, North Carolina.

April 4, 1984: Jack & Jerry Brisco over McDaniel & Youngblood, Spartanburg, South Carolina.

May 5, 1984: Wahoo McDaniel & Mark Youngblood regain the belts, Greensboro, North Carolina.

May 8, 1984: Ivan Koloff & Don Kernodle beat McDaniel & Youngblood, Raleigh, North Carolina.

October 20, 1984: Dusty Rhodes & Manny Fernandez defeat Koloff & Kernodle, Greensboro, North Carolina.

March 18, 1985: Ivan & Nikita Koloff over Rhodes & Fernandez, Fayetteville, North Carolina.

* Krusher Khrushchev (Barry Darsow) joins the Russians' stable, and the three men begin defending the tag titles in various combinations.

July 9, 1985: The Rock 'n Roll Express (Ricky Morton & Robert Gibson) defeat Koloff & Khrushchev, Shelby, North Carolina.

October 13, 1985: Ivan & Nikita Koloff beat Morton & Gibson, Charlotte, North Carolina.

November 28, 1985: The Rock 'n Roll Express regain the titles, Greensboro, North Carolina.

February 2, 1986: The Midnight Express (Dennis Condrey & Bobby Eaton) over Morton & Gibson, Atlanta, Georgia.

August 16, 1986: The Rock 'n Roll Express win back the titles, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

December 6, 1986: Manny Fernandez & Rick Rude beat Morton & Gibson, Atlanta, Georgia.

May 26, 1987: The Rock 'n Roll Express regain the titles, Spokane, Washington.

September 29, 1987: Arn Anderson & Tully Blanchard defeat Morton & Gibson, Misenheimer, North Carolina.

March 27, 1988: Barry Windham & Lex Luger beat Anderson & Blanchard, Greensboro, North Carolina.

April 20, 1988: Arn Anderson & Tully Blanchard regain the belts, Jacksonville, Florida.

September 10, 1988: The Midnight Express (Bobby Eaton & Stan Lane) defeat Anderson & Blanchard, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

October 29, 1988: The Road Warriors (Hawk & Animal) beat the Express, New Orleans, Louisiana.

April 2, 1989: The Varsity Club (Mike Rotundo & Steve Williams) defeat The Warriors, New Orleans, Louisiana.

May 7, 1989: Rotundo & Williams defend the titles against the Road Warriors with guest referee Nikita Koloff. Dan Spivey and Kevin Sullivan run in and attack Koloff on the champions' behalf, and the team is stripped of the belts as a result.

June 14, 1989: The Fabulous Freebirds (Michael Hayes & Jimmy Garvin) beat the Midnight Express in the finals of an 8-team tournament.

November 1, 1989: Rick & Scott Steiner over the Freebirds, Atlanta, Georgia.

May 19, 1990: Doom (Butch Reed & Ron Simmons) defeat the Steiners, Washington, DC.

February 24, 1991: The Fabulous Freebirds (Michael Hayes & Jimmy Garvin) beat Doom, Phoenix, Arizona.

March 9, 1991: Rick & Scott Steiner over the Freebirds, Montgomery, Alabama.

With the NWA no longer operating as an organization, the Steiner brothers are regarded as the last NWA world tag team champions and the first WCW world tag team champions.

July, 1991: The Steiners are stripped of the WCW tag titles when Scott Steiner is unable to compete due to a torn bicep injury.

September 5, 1991: The Enforcers (Arn Anderson & Larry Zbysko) defeat Rick Steiner & Bill Kazmaier in the tournament final, Augusta, Georgia.

November 19, 1991: Dustin Rhodes & Ricky Steamboat over Anderson & Zbysko, Savannah, Georgia.

January 16, 1992: Arn Anderson & Bobby Eaton beat Rhodes & Steamboat, Jacksonville, Florida.

May 3, 1992: Rick & Scott Steiner defeat Anderson & Eaton, Chicago, Illinois.

July 5, 1992: Terry Gordy & Steve Williams over the Steiners, Atlanta, Georgia.

* A tournament to fill the NWA tag title vacancy is held on July 12, 1992, and is won by Terry Gordy & Steve Williams (who defeat Barry Windham & Dustin Rhodes). The NWA titles are unified with the WCW titles, and both championships are co-recognized.

September 21, 1992: Barry Windham & Dustin Rhodes beat Gordy & Williams, Atlanta, Georgia.

November 18, 1992: Shane Douglas & Ricky Steamboat over Windham & Rhodes, Macon, Georgia.

March 2, 1993: The Hollywood Blondes (Steve Austin & Brian Pillman) win the titles, Macon, Georgia.

August 18, 1993: Arn Anderson & Paul Roma defeat Austin and Lord Steven Regal (subbing for an injured Pillman), Daytona Beach, Florida.

September, 1993: WCW withdraws from the NWA, and co-recognition of the tag team champions as both WCW and NWA champions is dropped, with Anderson and Roma becoming known strictly as the WCW world title holders.

September 19, 1993: The Nasty Boys (Jerry Saggs & Brian Knobbs) beat Anderson & Roma, Houston, Texas.

October 4, 1993: Marcus Alexander Bagwell & 2 Cold Scorpio defeat The Nasty Boys, Columbus, Georgia.

October 24, 1993: The Nasty Boys regain the belts, New Orleans, Louisiana.

May 22, 1994: Cactus Jack & Kevin Sullivan over The Nasty Boys, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

July 17, 1994: Pretty Wonderful (Paul Orndorff & Paul Roma) beat Cactus & Sullivan, Orlando, Florida.

September 25, 1994: Stars & Stripes (Marcus Alexander Bagwell & Del "The Patriot" Wilkes) defeat Orndorff & Roma, Atlanta, Georgia.

October 23, 1994: Pretty Wonderful regains the titles, Detroit, Michigan.

November 16, 1994: Stars & Stripes wins back the titles, Jacksonville, Florida.

December 8, 1994: Harlem Heat (Stevie Ray & Booker T) defeat Bagwell & Wilkes, Atlanta, Georgia.

May 21, 1995: The Nasty Boys beat Harlem Heat, St. Petersburg, Florida.

June 24, 1995: Harlem Heat regain the titles, Orlando, Florida.

July 22, 1995: Bunkhouse Buck & Dick Slater over Harlem Heat, Atlanta, Georgia.

September 17, 1995: Harlem Heat win back the titles, Asheville, North Carolina.

September 18, 1995: The American Males (Marcus Bagwell & Scotty Riggs) defeat Harlem Heat, Johnson City, Tennessee.

September 27, 1995: Harlem Heat over The American Males, Atlanta, Georgia.

January 22, 1996: Sting & Lex Luger beat Harlem Heat, Las Vegas, Nevada.

June 24, 1996: Harlem Heat regain the titles in a triangle match against Sting/Luger and Rick & Scott Steiner, Charlotte, North Carolina.

July 24, 1996: Rick & Scott Steiner defeat Harlem Heat, Cincinnati, Ohio.

July 27, 1996: Harlem Heat win back the titles, Dayton, Ohio.

September 23, 1996: Public Enemy (Rocco Rock & Johnny Grunge) over Harlem Heat, Birmingham, Alabama.

October 1, 1996: Harlem Heat regain the belts, Canton, Ohio.

October 27, 1996: The Outsiders (Kevin Nash & Scott Hall) defeat Harlem Heat, Las Vegas, Nevada.

January 26, 1997: Rick & Scott Steiner beat The Outsiders, Cedar Rapids, Iowa.

January 27, 1997: The Steiners are forced to return the titles to The Outsiders by WCW Vice President Eric Bischoff, who is a fellow member of the New World Order with the Outsiders.

February 23, 1997: The Giant (Paul Wight) & Lex Luger beat The Outsiders, San Francisco, California.

February 24, 1997: The Giant & Luger are forced to return the titles.

October 13, 1997: Rick & Scott Steiner defeat Scott Hall & Syxx (Sean Waltman), who subs for an injured Kevin Nash, Tampa, Florida.

January 12, 1998: The Outsiders beat The Steiners, Jacksonville, Florida.

February 9, 1998: Rick & Scott Steiner regain the titles, El Paso, Texas.

February 22, 1998: The Outsiders win back the belts, San Francisco, California.

May 17, 1998: Sting & The Giant (Paul Wight) over The Outsiders, Worcester, Massachusetts.

June 4, 1998: The titles are vacated after Sting & The Giant break up. The Giant puts the belts on the line (with Brian Adams as his partner) against Lex Luger & Diamond Dallas Page; Page pins Adams to win the match, however WCW Chairman James J. Dillon declares that Sting and The Giant will wrestle a singles match with the winner picking a new partner, and that team will reign as new champions.

June 14, 1998: Sting defeats The Giant, Baltimore, Maryland.

June 15, 1998: Sting picks Kevin Nash as his partner, and the two are declared WCW world tag team champions, Uniondale, New York.

July 20, 1998: Scott Hall & The Giant over Sting & Nash, Salt Lake City, Utah.

October 25, 1998: Rick Steiner & Marcus "Buff" Bagwell defeat Scott Steiner (subbing for Scott Hall) & The Giant, Las Vegas, Nevada. During the match, Bagwell turns on his partner, and Rick Steiner wrestles (and wins) the match on his own.

October 26, 1998: Rick Steiner chooses Kenny Kaos as his new partner.

January, 1999: The titles are forfeited due to an injury to Rick Steiner.

February 21, 1999: Barry Windham & Curt Hennig defeat Chris Benoit & Dean Malenko in the finals of a tournament to win the belts, Oakland, California.

March 14, 1999: Chris Benoit & Dean Malenko beat Windham & Hennig, Louisville, Kentucky.

March 29, 1999: Rey Mysterio Jr. & Billy Kidman over Benoit & Malenko, Toronto, Ontario.

May 9, 1999: Raven & Perry Saturn beat Mysterio/Kidman and Benoit/Malenko in a three-way match, St. Louis, Missouri.

May 31, 1999: Diamond Dallas Page & Bam Bam Bigelow beat Perry Saturn & Kanyon (subbing for an injured Raven). Later in the evening, Page & Bigelow lose to Chris Benoit & Perry Saturn (subbing for Ric Flair, who leaves the ring during the match). Flair (then WCW President) declares that the titles cannot change hands due to an illegal partner substitution. Flair then gives the titles to the New Jersey Triad, consisting of Page, Bigelow and Kanyon, and the three are allowed to defend the belts in various combinations.

June 10, 1999: Chris Benoit & Perry Saturn defeat Page & Kanyon, Syracuse, New York.

June 13, 1999: The New Jersey Triad (Page & Kanyon) regains the titles, Baltimore, Maryland.

August 14, 1999: Harlem Heat over The Triad (Bigelow & Kanyon), Sturgis, South Dakota.

August 23, 1999: Barry & Kendall Windham defeat Harlem Heat, Las Vegas, Nevada.

September 12, 1999: Harlem Heat win back the belts, Winston-Salem, North Carolina.

October 18, 1999: Rey Misterio Jr. & Konnan (of The Filthy Animals) beat Harlem Heat, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

October 24, 1999: It's announced that Misterio and Konnan have been forced to forfeit the titles due to an injury to Misterio. A 3-team triangle match is announced to take place this same night.

October 24, 1999: Harlem Heat defeat Konnan & Kidman (of the Filthy Animals) and Hugh Morris & Brian Knobs (of the First Family), Halloween Havoc, Las Vegas, Nevada.

October 25, 1999: Konnan & Kidman (of the Filthy Animals) over Harlem Heat, Monday Nitro, Phoenix, Arizona.

November 22, 1999: Creative Control (Patrick and Gerald) beat The Filthy Animals, Monday Nitro, Detroit, Michigan.

December 7, 1999: Bret Hart and Goldberg defeat Creative Control, WCW Thunder, Madison, Wisconsin (taped December 5, 1999).

December 14, 1999: The Outsiders (Kevin Nash and Scott Hall) over Hart and Goldberg, New Orleans, Louisiana.

December 27, 1999: The Outsiders are stripped of the titles after Scott Hall no-shows a scheduled appearance, Monday Nitro, Houston, Texas.

January 3, 2000: David Flair and Crowbar (Devon Storm) defeat Kevin Nash and Scott Steiner in the finals of a "Lethal Lottery" tournament, Monday Nitro, Greenville, South Carolina.

January 19, 2000: The Mamalukes (Big Vito and Johnny Bull) beat Flair and Crowbar, WCW Thunder, Evansville, Indiana (taped January 18, 2000).

February, 2000: The titles change hands twice (with Ron and Don Harris winning the belts on one show, only to lose them back to the Mamalukes on another) on a WCW tour in Germany; the title changes are never acknowledged.

March 19, 2000: Ron and Don Harris over The Mamalukes, Uncensored, Miami, Florida.

April 10, 2000: The "new regime" (Eric Bischoff and Vince Russo) strips all WCW champions of their respective titles. All titles are declared vacant, Monday Nitro, Denver, Colorado.

A one-night tournament is announced to crown new WCW tag team champions.

April 16, 2000: Shane Douglas and Buff Bagwell beat Team Package (Lex Luger and Ric Flair) in the tournament final, Spring Stampede, Chicago, Illinois.

May 9, 2000: Buff Bagwell is arrested at the Thunder taping in Springfield, Illinois and is subsequently charged with assault by a WCW crew member. Bagwell is later suspended by WCW for 30 days without pay and unofficially forfeits his half of the tag team titles.

May 15, 2000: Kronic (Brian Adams and Bryan Clarke) defeat Shane Douglas and his replacement partner The Wall, WCW Monday Nitro, Biloxi, Missouri.

May 31, 2000: Sean Stasiak and Chuck Palumbo over Kronic via disqualification in a match in which the titles change hands on a DQ, WCW Thunder, Boise, Idaho (taped May 30).

July 9, 2000: Kronic (Brian Adams and Bryan Clarke) regain the titles, Bash at the Beach, Daytona Beach, Florida.

August 13, 2000: Dark Carnival (Vampiro and The Great Muta) beat Kronic, WCW New Blood Rising, Vancouver, British Columbia.

August 14, 2000: The Filthy Animals (Rey Mysterio Jr. and Juventud Guerrera) defeat Dark Carnival, WCW Monday Nitro, Kelowna, British Columbia.

September 18, 2000: Disqo (Disco Inferno) voluntarily offers to strip Mysterio and Guerrera of their tag team titles if he's unable to defeat The Cat in a match for The Cat's commissioner job. The Cat agrees, and wins the match, thereby stripping Mysterio and Guerrera of their titles, WCW Monday Nitro, Kitchener, Ontario.

September 25, 2000: Mark Jindrak and Sean O'Haire defeat Rey Mysterio Jr./Juventud Guerrera, 3 Count, The Harris Brothers, Lt. Loco/Corporal Cajun, and The Jung Dragons in a tag team title battle royal to capture the belts, WCW Monday Nitro, Uniondale, New York.

October 11, 2000: Chavo "Lt. Loco" Guerrero and Lash "Cpl. Cajun" Leroux beat Jindrak and O'Haire, WCW Thunder, Sydney, Australia (taped October 8).

October 11, 2000: Appointed booker Mike Sanders orders an immediate rematch, and Mark Jindrak and Sean O'Haire regain the titles, WCW Thunder, Sydney, Australia (taped October 8).

November 16, 2000: Alex Wright and General Rection (Hugh Morrus) defeat Jindrak and O'Haire, WCW Millenium Final, Obernhausen, Germany.

WCW announces Alex Wright and Disqo (Disco Inferno) as the new WCW tag team champions. General Rection's participation in the title change (substituting for Disqo) isn't acknowledged.

November 20, 2000: The Perfect Event (Shawn Stasiak and Chuck Palumbo) defeat Wright and Elix Skipper (substituting for an injured Disqo), WCW Monday Nitro, Augusta, Georgia.

November 26, 2000: Kevin Nash and Diamond Dallas Page over The Perfect Event, WCW Mayhem, Milwaukee, Wisconsin.

December 4, 2000: Nash and Page are stripped of the titles by WCW CEO Ric Flair after WCW Commissioner Mike Sanders produces video footage to prove that the illegal man was pinned in the previous title change. The titles are returned to The Perfect Event. The events take place on WCW Monday Nitro, Lincoln, Nebraska.

December 17, 2000: Kevin Nash and Diamond Dallas Page regain the titles, WCW Starrcade, Washington, D.C.

January 14, 2001: Chuck Palumbo and Sean O'Haire (of the Natural Born Thrillers) beat Nash and Page, WCW Sin, Indianapolis, Indiana.

NWA\WCW US Title History

1975: Harley Race defeats Johnny Weaver in the tournament final to become the first National Wrestling Alliance United States champion, Tallahassee, Florida.

July 3, 1975: Johnny Valentine beats Race, Greensboro, North Carolina.

October 4, 1975: Valentine suffers career ending injuries in a plane crash; the title is vacated.

November 9, 1975: Terry Funk over Paul Jones in the finals of a 16-man tournament, Greensboro, North Carolina.

November, 1975: Paul Jones defeats Funk.

March 16, 1976: Blackjack Mulligan beats Jones.

October 16, 1976: Paul Jones regains the title.

January, 1977: Blackjack Mulligan wins back the title.

1977: Bobo Brazil defeats Mulligan, Norfolk, Virginia.

July 29, 1977: "Nature Boy" Ric Flair over Brazil, Richmond, Virginia.

November 11, 1977: Ricky Steamboat beats Flair, Richmond, Virginia.

February, 1978: Blackjack Mulligan defeats Steamboat.

March, 1978: Mr. Wrestling (Tim Woods) over Mulligan, Greensboro, North Carolina.

April 9, 1978: "Nature Boy" Ric Flair beats Woods, Charlotte, North Carolina.

December 18, 1978: Ricky Steamboat defeats Flair, Toronto, Ontario.

April 1, 1979: "Nature Boy" Ric Flair regains the title, Greensboro, North Carolina.

August 12, 1979: Flair becomes one half of the NWA world tag team championships; he vacates the U.S. title.

September 1, 1979: "Superfly" Jimmy Snuka defeats Ricky Steamboat in the finals of a 12-man tournament, Charlotte, North Carolina.

April 19, 1980: "Nature Boy" Ric Flair over Snuka, Greensboro, North Carolina.

July 26, 1980: Greg Valentine beats Flair, Charlotte, North Carolina.

November 24, 1980: "Nature Boy" Ric Flair regains the title, Greenville, South Carolina.

January 27, 1981: Roddy Piper defeats Flair, Raleigh, North Carolina.

August 8, 1981: Wahoo McDaniel beats Piper, Greensboro, North Carolina.

September, 1981: McDaniel is stripped of the title after being injured by Abdullah the Butcher and therefore unable to defend. A tournament is ordered to fill the vacancy.

October 4, 1981: Sgt. Slaughter over Ricky Steamboat in the tournament final, Charlotte, North Carolina.

May 21, 1982: Wahoo McDaniel defeats Slaughter, Richmond, Virginia.

June 7, 1982: Sgt. Slaughter is awarded the title when McDaniel is unable to show up for the scheduled title match as a result of having sustained an injured left leg at the hands of Don Muraco and Roddy Piper, Greenville, South Carolina.

August 22, 1982: Wahoo McDaniel recaptures the championship, Charlotte, North Carolina.

November 4, 1982: Greg Valentine over McDaniel, Norfolk, Virginia.

April 16, 1983: Roddy Piper defeats Valentine, Greensboro, North Carolina.

April 30, 1983: Greg Valentine is awarded the title when the match is stopped due to a cut over Piper's left ear that rendered him unable to continue.

December 14, 1983: Dick Slater defeats Valentine, Shelby, North Carolina.

April 21, 1984: Ricky Steamboat beats Slater, Greensboro, North Carolina.

June 24, 1984: Wahoo McDaniel over Steamboat, Greensboro, North Carolina. The title is held up and vacated following the match due to the interference of Tully Blanchard, who had hit Steamboat in the head with a chair during the match.

October 7, 1984: Wahoo McDaniel reclaims the belt by defeating Manny Fernandez in the tournament final, Charlotte, North Carolina.

March 23, 1985: Magnum T.A. (Terry Allen) beats McDaniel, Charlotte, North Carolina.

July 21, 1985: Tully Blanchard defeats Allen, Charlotte, North Carolina.

November 28, 1985: Magnum T.A. regains the title, Greensboro, North Carolina.

May 29, 1986: Magnum T.A. is stripped of the title for attacking NWA President Bob Geigel.

August 17, 1986: Nikita Koloff defeats Magnum T.A. in a best-of-seven series to fill the vacancy.

September 28, 1986: Koloff beats Wahoo McDaniel for the NWA National heavyweight title; the title is unified with the U.S. title.

July 11, 1987: Lex Luger over Koloff, Greensboro, North Carolina.

November 26, 1987: Dusty Rhodes defeats Luger, Chicago, Illinois.

April 15, 1988: Rhodes is stripped of the title and suspended from competition for attacking NWA President Jim Crockett with a baseball bat.

May 13, 1988: Barry Windham beats Nikita Koloff in the tournament final, Houston, Texas.

February 20, 1989: Lex Luger over Windham, Chicago, Illinois.

May 7, 1989: Michael Hayes defeats Luger, Nashville, Tennessee.

May 22, 1989: Lex Luger regains the title, Bluefield, West Virginia.

October 27, 1990: Stan Hansen beats Luger, Chicago, Illinois.

December 16, 1990: Lex Luger wins back the title, St. Louis, Missouri.

January, 1991: With the NWA no longer in operations, the title is recognized exclusively as the World Championship Wrestling (WCW) United States Heavyweight Championship.

July 14, 1991: Luger wins the WCW World Title and promptly vacates the U.S. title.

August 25, 1991: Sting (Steve Borden) defeats Steve Austin in the tournament final, Atlanta, Georgia.

November 19, 1991: "Ravishing" Rick Rude beats Sting, Savannah, Georgia.

December, 1992: Rude is stripped of the title for failing to defend it (he was injured); the title is vacated.

January 11, 1993: Dustin Rhodes over Ricky Steamboat, Atlanta, Georgia. This match was initially scheduled to be a match to determine the number one contender, but following the vacancy of the title, it was decided that the winner of this match would be declared the new champion.

May, 1993: The title is declared vacant following a match between Rhodes and Rick Rude in which there is a controversial double-pin situation. Several rematches take place with no clear cut winner.

August 30, 1993: Dustin Rhodes defeats Rick Rude in a rematch for the vacant title, Atlanta, Georgia.

December 27, 1993: "Stunning" Steve Austin beats Rhodes, Charlotte, North Carolina.

August 24, 1994: Ricky Steamboat over Austin, Cedar Rapids, Iowa.

September 18, 1994: "Stunning" Steve Austin is awarded the title via forfeit when Steamboat is unable to defend the title due to a back injury, Roanoke, Virginia.

September 18, 1994: Hacksaw Jim Duggan defeats Steve Austin, Roanoke, Virginia.

December 27, 1994: Big Van Vader over Duggan, Nashville, Tennessee.

April, 1995: Vader is stripped of the title by WCW Commissioner Nick Bockwinkel for committing multiple offenses.

June 18, 1995: Sting beats Meng in the tournament final, Dayton, Ohio.

November 13, 1995: Kensuke Sasaki defeats Sting, Tokyo, Japan.

December 27, 1995: The One Man Gang is awarded the title after Sasaki defends against him and vacates the belt thereafter, Nashville, Tennessee.

January 29, 1996: Konnan beats the Gang, Canton, Ohio.

July 7, 1996: "Nature Boy" Ric Flair over Konnan, Daytona Beach, Florida.

November, 1996: The title is declared vacant after Flair suffers a shoulder injury.

December 29, 1996: Eddy Guerrero defeats Diamond Dallas Page in the tournament final, Nashville, Tennessee.

March 16, 1997: Dean Malenko beats Guerrero, Charleston, South Carolina.

June 9, 1997: Jeff Jarrett over Malenko, Boston, Massachusetts.

August 21, 1997: Steve McMichael defeats Jarrett, Nashville, Tennessee.

September 15, 1997: Curt Hennig beats McMichael, Charlotte, North Carolina.

December 28, 1997: Diamond Dallas Page over Hennig, Washington, DC.

April 19, 1998: Raven defeats Page, Denver, Colorado.

April 20, 1998: Bill Goldberg beats Raven, Colorado Springs, Colorado.

July 6, 1998: Goldberg wins the WCW world title; the U.S. title is vacated.

July 20, 1998: Bret "The Hitman" Hart defeats Diamond Dallas Page, Salt Lake City, Utah. Hart and Page had been deemed the top two contenders after Goldberg gave up the title.

August 10, 1998: Lex Luger over Hart, Rapid City, South Dakota.

August 13, 1998: Bret Hart regains the title, Fargo, North Dakota.

October 26, 1998: Diamond Dallas Page beats Hart, Phoenix, Arizona.

November 30, 1998: Bret Hart wins back the title, Chattanooga, Tennessee.

February 8, 1999: Roddy Piper defeats Hart, Buffalo, New York.

February 21, 1999: Scott Hall beats Piper, Oakland, California.

March 18, 1999: Hall is stripped of the title by WCW President Ric Flair due to injury.

April 11, 1999: "Big Poppa Pump" Scott Steiner beats Booker T. in the tournament final, Tacoma, Washington.

July 5, 1999: Steiner is stripped of the title due to injury. David Flair is subsequently declared the new champion, Atlanta, Georgia.

August 9, 1999: Chris Benoit over Flair, Nampa, Idaho.

September 12, 1999: Sid Vicious defeats Benoit, Winston-Salem, North Carolina.

October 24, 1999: Goldberg beats Sid, Halloween Havoc, Las Vegas, Nevada. The match was stopped due to a bloody cut to Sid that leaves him unable to continue.

October 25, 1999: Bret Hart over Goldberg, Monday Nitro, Phoenix, Arizona.

November 1, 1999: Bret Hart forfeits the title and attempts to give it back to Goldberg due to Hart's displeasure with winning the title due to outside interference from Kevin Nash and Scott Hall. The belt was stolen by Hall, but Hall was never acknowledged as champion.

November 8, 1999: Scott Hall defeats Sid Vicious, Bret Hart and Goldberg in a Texas Tornado Ladder Match (with special referee Kevin Nash), Monday Nitro, Indianapolis, Indiana.

December 19, 1999: Scott Hall is stripped of the title after an injury leaves him unable to defend; Chris Benoit (the scheduled challenger) is awarded the title and defends it successfully that night against Jeff Jarrett in a Ladder Match, Washington, DC.

December 20, 1999: Jeff Jarrett defeats Benoit in a Ladder Match rematch, Monday Nitro, Baltimore, Maryland.

January 16, 2000: Jeff Jarrett is stripped of the title after a concussion leaves him unable to defend, Souled Out, Cincinatti, Ohio.

January 17, 2000: WCW Commissioner Kevin Nash awards the title back to Jeff Jarrett, Monday Nitro.

April 10, 2000: The "new regime" (Eric Bischoff and Vince Russo) strips all WCW champions of their respective titles. All titles are declared vacant, Monday Nitro, Denver, Colorado.

A one-night tournament is announced to crown a new U.S. Champion.

April 16, 2000: Scott Steiner defeats Sting in the tournament final, Spring Stampede, Chicago, Illinois.

July 9, 2000: Scott Steiner is stripped of the title by Commissioner Ernest "The Cat" Miller for utilizing his Steiner Recliner move in a match against Mike Awesome, a move that The Cat had previously banned. These events took place at the Bash at the Beach, Daytona Beach, Florida.

An eight man tournament is announced to crown a new champion. Among the participants in the tournament are Mike Awesome, Kanyon, Buff Bagwell, Lance Storm, Shane Douglas, Kidman, Vampiro and The Great Muta.

July 18, 2000: Lance Storm defeats Mike Awesome in the tournament final to become the new WCW United States Champion, WCW Monday Nitro, Auburn Hills, Michigan.

September 22, 2000: Terry Funk beats Storm, Amarillo, Texas.

September 23, 2000: Lance Storm regains the title, Lubbock, Texas.

October 29, 2000: General Rection (Hugh Morrus) pins "Hacksaw" Jim Duggan in a handicap match with the title on the line (Storm and Duggan vs. Rection) and therefore becomes the new champion, WCW Halloween Havoc, Las Vegas, Nevada.

November 13, 2000: Lance Storm regains the title, WCW Monday Nitro, London, England (taped November 10).

November 26, 2000: General Rection regains the title, WCW Mayhem, Milwaukee, Wisconsin.

January 14, 2001: Shane Douglas over Rection, WCW Sin, Indianapolis, Indiana.

February 5, 2001: Rick Steiner beats Douglas, WCW Monday Nitro, Tupelo, Mississippi.

March 18, 2001: Booker T defeats Steiner, WCW Greed, Jacksonville, Florida.

NWA/WCW World Title History History

October, 1948: Orville Brown, the reigning Midwest Wrestling Association (MWA) world heavyweight champion, is declared the first National Wrestling Alliance (NWA) world champion; the MWA is absorbed into the NWA.

November 27, 1949: Lou Thesz is awarded the title when Brown is unable to defend following an automobile accident on November 1st. A unification match with Thesz had been scheduled for November 25 in St. Louis, Missouri, as Thesz was the reigning National Wrestling Association world champion (having defeated Bill Longson on July 20, 1948 in Indianapolis, Indiana).

July 27, 1950: Lou Thesz defeats Gorgeous George to win the American Wrestling Association world title (the Boston territory), Chicago, Illinois. The title is unified with Thesz's other world titles.

May 21, 1952: Lou Thesz beats Baron Michele Leone for the Los Angeles Olympic Auditorium version of the world title, Los Angeles, California. Thesz unifies the title with his others to become the undisputed NWA world heavyweight wrestling champion.

March 15, 1956: Whipper Billy Watson defeats Thesz by count out, Toronto, Ontario.

November 9, 1956: Lou Thesz regains the title from Watson, St. Louis, Missouri.

June 14, 1957: Thesz loses to Edouard Carpentier in Chicago, Illinois when he's unable to continue due to a back injury. The NWA rules that the title cannot change hands due to injury and gives the title back to Thesz.

November 14, 1957: Dick Hutton beats Thesz, Toronto, Ontario.

January 9, 1959: Pat O'Connor defeats Hutton, St. Louis, Missouri.

June 30, 1961: Buddy Rogers over O'Connor, Chicago, Illinois.

January 24, 1963: Lou Thesz wins back the title by beating Rogers, Toronto, Ontario.

January 7, 1966: Gene Kiniski beats Thesz, St. Louis, Missouri.

February 11, 1969: Dory Funk Jr. defeats Kiniski, Tampa, Florida.

March 24, 1973: Harley Race over Funk, Kansas City, Missouri.

July 20, 1973: Jack Brisco beats Race, Houston, Texas.

December 2, 1974: Shohei "Giant" Baba defeats Brisco, Kagoshima, Japan.

December 9, 1974: Jack Brisco regains the title from Baba, Toyohashi, Japan.

December 10, 1975: Terry Funk beats Brisco, Miami, Florida.

February 6, 1977: Harley Race wins the title from Funk, Toronto, Ontario.

August 21, 1979: Dusty Rhodes defeats Race, Tampa, Florida.

August 26, 1979: Harley Race regains the title from Rhodes, Orlando, Florida.

October 31, 1979: The Giant Baba beats Race, Nagoya, Japan.

November 7, 1979: Harley Race regains the title from Baba, Amagasaki, Japan.

September 4, 1980: The Giant Baba wins back the championship, Saga, Japan.

September 9, 1980: Harley Race wins his fifth title, Ohtsu, Japan.

April 27, 1981: "Wildfire" Tommy Rich defeats Race, Augusta, Georgia.

May 1, 1981: Harley Race regains the title from Rich, Gainsville, Georgia.

June 21, 1981: Dusty Rhodes beats Race, Atlanta, Georgia.

September 17, 1981: "Nature Boy" Ric Flair defeats Race, Kansas City, Missouri.

February 9, 1983: The Midnight Rider beats Flair, Tampa, Florida. The Rider is ordered to unmask by NWA President Bob Geigel, and is revealed to be Dusty Rhodes, who at the time was suspended from competition. The title is returned to Flair.

June 10, 1983: Harley Race over Flair, St. Louis, Missouri.

November 24, 1983: "Nature Boy" Ric Flair regains the title, Greensboro, North Carolina.

March 21, 1984: Harley Race regains the title from Flair, Wellington, New Zealand.

March 23, 1984: "Nature Boy" Ric Flair wins back the title, Kallang, Singapore.

May 6, 1984: Kerry Von Erich defeats Flair, Irving, Texas.

May 24, 1984: "Nature Boy" Ric Flair regains the title, Yokosuka, Japan.

July 25, 1986: Dusty Rhodes beats Flair, Greensboro, North Carolina.

August 7, 1986: "Nature Boy" Ric Flair wins his fifth title, St. Louis, Missouri.

September 25, 1987: Ronnie Garvin defeats Flair, Detroit, Michigan.

November 26, 1987: "Nature Boy" Ric Flair over Garvin, Chicago, Illinois.

February 20, 1989: Ricky "The Dragon" Steamboat beats Flair, Chicago, Illinois.

May 7, 1989: "Nature Boy" Ric Flair regains the title, Nashville, Tennessee.

July 7, 1990: Sting (Steve Borden) defeats Flair, Baltimore, Maryland.

January 11, 1991: "Nature Boy" Ric Flair wins back the title, East Rutherford, New Jersey. With the NWA not current operating as an organization, the world title is referred to exclusively as the World Championship Wrestling (WCW) world heavyweight title (WCW would officially withdraw from the NWA in September, 1993). Flair is declared the first WCW world champion.

July 1, 1991: Flair is stripped of the title after he is unable to come to a contractual agreement with WCW. Flair leaves and signs with the WWF.

July 14, 1991: Lex Luger beats Barry Windham, Baltimore, Maryland. WCW had declared Luger and Windham to be the top contenders for the vacant title.

February 29, 1992: Sting defeats Luger, Milwaukee, Wisconsin.

July 12, 1992: Big Van Vader over Sting, Albany, Georgia.

August 2, 1992: Ron Simmons beats Vader, Baltimore, Maryland.

December 30, 1992: Big Van Vader regains the title from Simmons, Baltimore, Maryland.

March 11, 1993: Sting defeats Vader, London, England.

March 17, 1993: Vader regains the title, Dublin, Ireland.

December 27, 1993: "Nature Boy" Ric Flair beats Vader, Charlotte, North Carolina.

The title is held up after a match against Ricky "The Dragon" Steamboat on April 17, 1994 in Rosemont, Illinois. The match had ended with a double pin.

April 24, 1994: "Nature Boy" Ric Flair beats Steamboat in a rematch, Atlanta, Georgia.

June 23, 1994: Ric Flair defeats Sting for the WCW International (formerly WCW/NWA) title and unifies it with the WCW world title, Charleston, South Carolina.

July 17, 1994: Hulk Hogan over Flair, Bash at the Beach, Orlando, Florida.

October 29, 1995: Paul "The Giant" Wight beats Hogan by disqualification, Detroit, Michigan. Hogan's manager, Jimmy Hart, had signed a contract that stated the title can change hands on a disqualification.

November 6, 1995: The Giant is stripped of the title when WCW officials decide the title win over Hogan was bogus. The title is declared vacant.

November 26, 1995: "Macho Man" Randy Savage wins the title in a 60-man, 3 ring battle royale (WCW's World War 3), Norfolk, Virginia.

December 27, 1995: "Nature Boy" Ric Flair over Savage, Nashville, Tennessee.

January 22, 1996: "Macho Man" Randy Savage regains the title, Las Vegas, Nevada.

February 11, 1996: "Nature Boy" Ric Flair wins back the title, St. Petersburg, Florida.

April 22, 1996: The Giant beats Flair, Albany, Georgia.

August 10, 1996: Hulk Hogan defeats The Giant, Sturgis, South Dakota.

August 4, 1997: Lex Luger over Hogan, Auburn Hills, Michigan.

August 9, 1997: Hulk Hogan regains the title, Sturgis, South Dakota.

December 28, 1997: Sting beats Hogan, Washington, DC.

January 8, 1998: Sting is ordered to surrender the title by WCW Commissioner J.J. Dillon as a result of controversial endings in both the match in which he won the title from Hogan, and the rematch the next night. The title is declared vacant.

February 22, 1998: Sting defeats Hulk Hogan in a rematch for the vacant title, San Francisco, California.

April 19, 1998: "Macho Man" Randy Savage beats Sting, Denver, Colorado.

April 20, 1998: Hulk Hogan over Savage, Colorado Springs, Colorado.

July 6, 1998: Bill Goldberg defeats Hogan, Atlanta, Georgia.

December 27, 1998: Kevin Nash beats Goldberg, Washington, DC.

January 4, 1999: Hulk Hogan over Nash, Atlanta, Georgia.

March 14, 1999: "Nature Boy" Ric Flair defeats Hogan, Louisville, Kentucky.

April 11, 1999: Diamond Dallas Page beats Flair, Hulk Hogan and Sting in a Four Corners Match, Tacoma, Washington.

April 26, 1999: Sting over Page, Monday Nitro, Fargo, North Dakota.

April 26, 1999: Diamond Dallas Page regains the title (the same night he lost it) by defeating Sting, Kevin Nash and Bill Goldberg in a Four Way match, Monday Nitro, Fargo, North Dakota.

May 9, 1999: Kevin Nash beats Page, St. Louis, Missouri.

July 11, 1999: "Macho Man" Randy Savage (who teams with Sid Vicious) defeats Nash (who teams with Sting) in a tag team match with the title on the line.

July 12, 1999: Hulk Hogan defeats Savage, Jacksonville, Florida.

September 12, 1999: Sting over Hogan, Winston-Salem, North Carolina.

October 24, 1999: Sting issues an open challenge following a controversial title match with Hulk Hogan (in which Hogan, upset with management, simply laid down and allowed Sting to pin him). The challenge is accepted by Goldberg, who defeats Sting, Halloween Havoc, Las Vegas, Nevada.

October 25, 1999: It is declared that the Sting vs. Goldberg match the night before wasn't scheduled to be a title match. Goldberg is stripped of the title, and a 32-man tournament is announced, Monday Nitro, Phoenix, Arizona.

November 21, 1999: Bret "Hitman" Hart beats Chris Benoit in the tournament final to win the title, WCW Mayhem, Toronto, Ontario.

January 16, 2000: Bret Hart is stripped of the title after a concussion leaves him unable to defend; it is determined that his scheduled challenger, Sid Vicious, will wrestle Chris Benoit for the vacant title.

January 16, 2000: Chris Benoit beats Sid Vicious, Souled Out, Cincinatti, Ohio.

January 17, 2000: The WCW title is vacated after Benoit walks out of WCW.

January 24, 2000: Sid Vicious defeats Kevin Nash for the vacant title, Monday Nitro, Los Angeles, California.

January 26, 2000: Sid Vicious is stripped of the title by WCW Commissioner Nash, WCW Thunder, Las Vegas, Nevada (taped January 25, 2000).

January 26, 2000: Kevin Nash awards himself the WCW title, WCW Thunder, Las Vegas, Nevada.

January 26, 2000: Sid Vicious beats Nash and Ron and Don Harris in a Steel Cage Triangle Match to win the title, WCW Thunder, Las Vegas, Nevada.

April 10, 2000: The "new regime" (Eric Bischoff and Vince Russo) strips all WCW champions of their respective titles. All titles are declared vacant, Monday Nitro, Denver, Colorado.

April 16, 2000: Jeff Jarrett defeats Diamond Dallas Page in a match to determine the new champion, Spring Stampede, Chicago, Illinois.

April 24, 2000: Actor David Arquette defeats Eric Bischoff in a match with the stipulation that if Arquette won, Diamond Dallas Page would get a title shot against Jeff Jarrett later in the evening, Monday Nitro, Rochester, New York.

April 24, 2000: Diamond Dallas Page over Jarrett in a cage match, Monday Nitro, Rochester, New York.

April 26, 2000: A tag team match is announced pitting Diamond Dallas Page and actor David Arquette against Jeff Jarrett and Eric Bischoff. A stipulation of the match is that the man to score the pin will win the title. WCW Thunder, Syracuse, New York.

April 26, 2000: David Arquette pins Eric Bischoff in the tag team match to win the title, WCW Thunder, Syracuse, New York (taped on April 25).

May 7, 2000: Jeff Jarrett beats David Arquette and Diamond Dallas Page in a Triple Cage Match, WCW Slamboree, Kansas City, Missouri.

May 15, 2000: Ric Flair defeats Jarrett, Monday Nitro, Biloxi, Missouri.

May 16, 2000: Ric Flair collapses following an in-ring segment due to an inner-ear equilibrium problem, WCW Thunder taping, Lafayette, Louisiana (aired on May 17).

May 22, 2000: Vince Russo strips Ric Flair of the title and presents it to former champion Jeff Jarrett, Monday Nitro, Grand Rapids, Michigan.

May 24, 2000: Kevin Nash beats Jeff Jarrett and Scott Steiner in a triple threat match, WCW Thunder, Saginaw, Michigan (taped on May 23).

May 29, 2000: Kevin Nash presents the title back to Ric Flair, Monday Nitro, Salt Lake City, Utah.

May 29, 2000: Jeff Jarrett over Ric Flair, Monday Nitro, Salt Lake City, Utah.

July 9, 2000: Jeff Jarrett is scheduled to defend the title against Hulk Hogan at the Bash at the Beach PPV in Daytona Beach, Florida. Controversy surrounds the event, as it is believed that Hogan had refused to job to Jarrett, something that management wanted Hogan to do. As the bell rang to start the match, Jarrett simply dropped to his back, after which a stunned Hogan placed one boot on his chest and got the pin. WCW head writer Vince Russo took the mic moments later and announced that Jarrett was still being recognized as champion, and would defend the title later in the evening against Booker T.

July 9, 2000: Booker T. defeats Jarrett for the title, Bash at the Beach, Daytona Beach, Florida.

August 28, 2000: Kevin Nash beats Booker T, WCW Monday Nitro, Las Cruces, New Mexico.

September 17, 2000: Booker T regains the title in a Caged Heat Match, WCW Fall Brawl, Buffalo, New York.

September 25, 2000: Booker T defends the title against Vince Russo in a Caged Heat Match on WCW Monday Nitro, Uniondale, New York. Both men appear to exit the cage at the same time, therefore it is uncertain as to who the WCW champion is.

September 27, 2000: Vince Russo declares himself to be the new WCW champion, WCW Thunder, Wilkes Barre, Pennsylvania (taped September 26). He indicates that because he's not a wrestler, the title will be forfeited.

October 2, 2000: Vince Russo forfeits the title and announces a Jeff Jarrett vs. Scott Steiner match to decide the new champion. WCW Commissioner The Cat overrules the decision and announces a Booker T vs. Sting match for the title. To remedy the situation, a tag match is booked featuring Jeff Jarrett and Booker T vs. Sting and Scott Steiner, in which the winning team will square off for the WCW title. Jarrett and Booker win the match.

October 2, 2000: Booker T defeats Jeff Jarrett in a "49ers Match" to win the WCW Title, WCW Monday Nitro, San Francisco, California.

November 26, 2000: Scott Steiner beats Booker T in a Caged Heat Straitjacket Match, WCW Mayhem, Milwaukee, Wisconsin.

March 26, 2001: Booker T regains the title, WCW Monday Nitro, Panama City, Florida.
